OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now produce final answer.</think>We’ll show one acceptable way to “read‐off” a function f(n) from keys written in the form

  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n).

In many cases (but not all) the division kₙ/n comes out exactly as an integer; when it does we can take that quotient to be f(n) and then the “leftover” is zero. When the division isn’t exact one common approach is to write
  kₙ = Q·n + R,
where Q = floor(kₙ/n) (the whole‐number part of the quotient) and R is the remainder.

In the “check–list” below we have been given five keys:

 • k₇ = 76  
 • k₈ = 224  
 • k₉ = 467  
 • k₁₁ = 1155  
 • k₁₂ = 2683

Let’s see what happens when we “divide” each key by its index.

1. For n = 7:  
 Divide 76 by 7. Since 10×7 = 70 and 11×7 = 77 is too high, we have  
  76 = 10·7 + 6.  
 Thus one may take f(7) = 10 (and g(7) = 6).

2. For n = 8:  
 Divide 224 by 8. Here 28×8 = 224 exactly, so there is no remainder. That is,  
  224 = 28·8 + 0.  
 Thus f(8) = 28 and g(8) = 0.

3. For n = 9:  
 Divide 467 by 9. Note that 51×9 = 459 and 52×9 = 468 is too high so we write  
  467 = 51·9 + 8.  
 Thus f(9) = 51 and g(9) = 8.

4. For n = 11:  
 Divide 1155 by 11. Since 105×11 = 1155 exactly, we have  
  1155 = 105·11 + 0.  
 Thus f(11) = 105 and g(11) = 0.

5. For n = 12:  
 Divide 2683 by 12. We see that 223×12 = 2676 and 224×12 = 2688 is too high so  
  2683 = 223·12 + 7.  
 Thus f(12) = 223 and g(12) = 7.

One acceptable answer is therefore:

 • k₇ = 10·7 + 6 ⟹ f(7) = 10  
 • k₈ = 28·8 + 0 ⟹ f(8) = 28  
 • k₉ = 51·9 + 8 ⟹ f(9) = 51  
 • k₁₁ = 105·11 + 0 ⟹ f(11) = 105  
 • k₁₂ = 223·12 + 7 ⟹ f(12) = 223

This shows one way to “extract” a function f(n) from the keys written in the form
  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n). 

Note that in some cases (like n = 8 and n = 11) the division is exact so that g(n)=0, while for other values (such as n = 7, 9, or 12) a nonzero remainder appears. Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.
